summary: Set in postwar Vienna, Austria, "The Third Man" stars Joseph Cotten as Holly Martins, a writer of pulp Westerns, who arrives penniless as a guest of his childhood chum Harry Lime (Orson Welles), only to find him dead. Martins develops a conspiracy theory after learning of a "third man" present at the time of Harry's death, running into interference from British officer Maj. Calloway (Trevor Howard) and falling head-over-heels for Harry's grief-stricken lover, Anna (Alida Valli).

Carol Reed's masterpiece is a stunning noir that bathes the screen in chiaroscuro  with canted angles used to perfection. The story is a simple, yet compelling mystery--with a great inversion on the femme fatale trope that has, in my opinion, has helped kept the story timeless. Memorably, this film produces what has to be the greatest cinematic character introduction of all time, coupled with the uniquely perfect zither-led score that still produces goosebumps even when played back in my mind's eye.

Joseph Cotten seems born to play Holly Martins. Alida Valli's performance is an ahead of its time portrayal of the Femme Fatale; told against a believable foundation of what would now be recognized as psychological trauma and a likely mentally abusive relationship with Orson Welles's Harry Lyme. 

The supporting cast fills every moment with intrigue, humor and mystery, driving the story forward. The Mid-Atlantic dialogue takes a break from its stilted position in the noir genre, thanks to the European setting of the film--and it offers color to the film's audial experience that contrasts nicely with the genre's famous black-and-white. 

This is not to suggest the black-and-white film is boring or monotonous. The lighting, camera work, and attention to detail make Vienna feel like a living creature in its own right. The visual texture and tactile feel achieved in this film is for my money, unmatched in the history of cinema--save for perhaps Ridley Scott's "Blade Runner." The editing that accompanies the cinematography uses the chiaroscuro and Dutch angles to heighten the film's visual language, and economically uses what is a lean and mighty score. 

And of all the iconic things which come out of this film, the zither-led score may be the most iconic.  It is beautiful, odd, conversational, and constantly driving the story forward with its vibrant strumming and use of musical dynamics. Very few films' scores are better than this.

In conclusion, every aspect of this film is on song. The direction, the acting, the writing and editing are phenomenal. This low-budget project, which almost didn't get made, shows how the power of storytelling and genre can transcend constraints of the trade and the larger artform itself, and result in one of the best films ever made.

Those who are so fortunate may come across that rare film which strikes them as totally flawless. My feeling is that "The Third Man" represents that most ultra-rare example of a film for which the term flawless doesn't go nearly far enough. Built atop a landscape of shocking desolation, the story bursts forth with the muted gaiety of its zither score, tilted shots immediately and beautifully intimating a world in which something is obviously askew. Into this world we are introduced to an interplay between characters that are as indelible as any in cinema, engaging within an atmospheric milieu that boasts the most evocative shots of cobblestones, dark alleyways, and perversely elongated shadows that could ever be hoped for in the dusky annals of noir. Layers of complexity and barely concealed themes invest the story with a degree of depth that matches its accessibility, resulting in a stirring cinematic statement whose thrills are never the least bit dulled by the profundity. The film boasts the most memorable character entrance in cinema as well as an ending sequence whose emotional weight rivals the iconic final image of John Wayne in "The Searchers." Like a monstrous shadow cast by an innocuous balloon bearing peasant, "The Third Man" delights in demonstrating to us that all is not as it seems.

During the Renaissance—you know, that period when, "for 30 years under the Borgias, they had warfare, terror, murder, and bloodshed"—alongside Michelangelo and da Vinci, artists developed an aesthetic, embodied cinematically in film noir, of bold but parasitical contrasts between light and dark called chiaroscuro, which literally translates as "light-dark" in Italian. The word itself is an oxymoronic juxtaposition that, like post-WWII Vienna and like Carol Reed's masterpiece, places side-by-side apparently incongruent elements in a fashion that is greater than the sum of its parts. As Michael Wilmington has written, the film "marks one of those unusual conjunctions of script, director, subject, cast and setting—and, of course, music—in which everything works." The often jarring discrepancies play off one another in suggestive ways: Giant shadows cast by tiny children, a zither score as jaunty as it is haunting in its strangeness, the corrupt cosmopolity sharing secrets and offices—even the names of our hero and villain, Holly and Harry, are so similar that they consistently are confused for one another (just like the other case of misidentification at the heart of the narrative). Yet these contradictions are not held in binary opposition but speak to something beyond the simple framework of good versus evil that a lesser film would be content with; rather, like the great wheel the film's most famous sequence revolves around, the distinction between going up and going down depends entirely on where you're standing.

AFI 100 Greatest Films - #57: I remember about six months ago I was looking to read The Heart of the Matter and found it in a larger collection of Graham Greene's work. Upon completing that, on the following page was a short story titled The Third Man, and the famous movie I had never seen came to mind, never even realizing Greene was involved in that. Greene explains in a short editor's note preceding this story that this was never even meant for publication and was simply part of his method when contracted to develop a script. I will quote Greene now, "To me it is almost impossible to write a film play without first writing a story. Even a film depends on more than plot, on a certain measure of characterization, on mood and atmosphere; and these seem to me almost impossible to capture for the first time in the dull shorthand of a script." Greene goes on to dedicate this story to director Carol Reed, "in admiration and affection and in memory of so many early morning Vienna hours at Maxim's, the Casanova, the Oriental", and when viewing these two quotes in the context of this film we can begin to see how Reed and Greene were able to achieve, along with the score, a certain feeling or ambiance amidst the streets of postwar Vienna that is really what many will remember most about this film. The roles were well cast and acted all around and while the story may not offer the opportunity to have our points of view challenged or change the way we think this film accomplishes exactly what it sets out to do, provide an engrossing mystery thriller that keeps the audience engaged until the conclusion. Before I started this film today I thought back and realized I didn't remember much at all about The Heart of the Matter but could still recall The Third Man fondly.

An American writer (Joseph Cotten) arrives in post-WWII occupied Vienna with the hopes of a job from an old friend, only to discover that the friend has mysteriously died; with the assistance/resistance of the friend's girlfriend (Alida Valli) and a taciturn military policeman (Trevor Howard), he attempts to solve the mystery. I first saw this when I was a teenager and perhaps too young to fully appreciate it, as I wasn't impressed that much back then; now, I can recognize how great the film is, the bristly intelligent, darkly comic script by Graham Greene, the brilliant filmmaking of director Carol Reed, the superlative performance by an ace cast, the haunting b&w cinematography of Robert Krasker and the taut editing of Oswald Hafenrichter; only the gratingly annoying, ever-constant zither music prevents it from being a perfect 10.

Aka a first time appraisal through 2019 eyes of a classic film that's 70 years old. In this fairly straight-forward and non-contrived noir thriller set contemporaneously to the time it was made, pulp fiction writer Holly Martins travels to Vienna to meet Harry Lime, an old friend only to find that he has died just before his arrival. Graham Greene's script, choke full of noir troupes and red herrings, is a simple and clever take of the genre that pulls its audience in deeper into mystery, just like its lead character. Playing with audience expectations to great effect, it feels ahead of its time. Meanwhile, Carol Reed's directing has equally stood the test of time rather well, as his monochrome work with cinematographer, Robert Krasker, is a visual joy. Shot mostly at night, on authentic location in post-WWII Vienna, the film is textually rich and their use of shadows and tilted and low angle shots perfectly complement the suspenseful mood of the film. However, the pacing of the film would be considered slow nowadays and Joseph Cotten's Martins, comes across as stiff and wooden, which allows Orson Welles's enigmatic Lime to steal the film from him with an incredibly charismatic and memorable performance that looms large over its 104mins duration even if he's absent on screen for most of that time. Of course, there is Anton Karas' famous zither music soundtrack which is now synonymous with the film. Intensely Austrian with a jolly, bouncy fun-fair ride feel to it, it may at times undercut the tension and frames the thriller in a more comedic light while presenting Harry Lime as a more cuddly villain (which he isn't), but it's now simply impossible to imagine the film without this utterly unique and inspired musical accompaniment.

Of all of the films from around this era that I have been told to watch because they are "important" this was certainly the best. Film noir is not generally a genre that I'm into, with the exception of Blade Runner (1982) and Mildred Pierce (1945), but this film managed to reel me in completely and I was never left wondering how much longer the film would be. The famous moment at which Orson Welles appears and everything beyond his arrival does completely overshadow the majority of the film but that works because we have already been warned that Harry Lime is a far more exciting presence than the nice but forgettable Holly Martins and casting no less than Orson Welles helps us to understand why Anna feels such an inextricable connection to him. This is a truly great film and it is more than just it's many iconic shots.

Holly Martins, Joseph Cotten, is a well-meaning writer who travels to Vienna to meet his longtime friend Harry Lime, Orson Welles, but when he arrives he discovers that Lime is dead. Lime is warned by several shady figures who knew Lime to leave Vienna but Martins remains steadfast in his belief that Lime was an innocent man. He falls in love with Anna, Alida Valli, who was Lime's girlfriend but she is unable or unwilling to let go of the memory of Lime and begin a romantic relationship with Martins. Evidence begins appearing that suggests that Lime is not in fact dead but has faked his death to escape from the enemies he made when he was alive.

The film has what seems like a convoluted plot but the circumstances surrounding Lime's disappearance are not really the focus of the film, Martins' dogged pursuit of Anna despite the fact she does not reciprocate his affections in anyway is sad but we feel similar to her when we witness Welles' magnetic charisma, on display from just one shot of him smirking. Martins establishes himself as a good person at the beginning of the film and doesn't change even as those around him urge him to let go of Anna or to criticize his friend who has essentially betrayed him. This could be frustrating but Cotten makes Martins believably earnest and sweet enough for us to trust that his character is genuine in his loyalty to two fickle people.

The cinematography and direction is stunning with Robert Krasker's camera capturing the darker parts of Vienna, specifically the sewers, in moody black and white. The final action scene features particularly gorgeous shots of Lime's fingers holding on to a grate while the harsh wind blows above him and various men running angrily through a dirty sewer. The final shot of Martins waiting for Anna with hands in pockets as she walks past him without a second glance is morose and melancholy and reinforces what the whole film has been about. I read that the film's look was strongly inspired by German expressionism and I can see the Secrets of a Soul (1926) template that it's working from.

The final reason that you absolutely must watch this film is the one, the only Orson Welles. I had read so much about what a presence he has and what a great director he was, I don't like The Magnificent Ambersons (1942), and been highly disbelieving in much the same way I am about James Dean. After seeing this film I have become a complete convert as I felt a rush go through my body at just seeing his face on screen. His face, his voice, his expressions, his everything are exciting and watching him do almost anything on screen is invigorating. I couldn't imagine anyone else playing Lime and he was one of the few characters heralded as exciting throughout the film that lived up to or even exceeded my expectations. If you don't have time for The Stranger (1946) or Citizen Kane (1941) then this is an easy hour and 48 minutes to marvel at.

The suspenseful noir classic The Third Man (1949) is as great as old films get. Director Carol Reed uses careful lighting to illuminate just enough of characters to see them in the dim rooms and dark streets of post WWII Vienna. Reed's wide shots of the city rubble and building doorways is exquisite direction. The highly decorated sets and rubble filled city ruins of Vienna are the perfect backdrop to this intriguing thriller. Around every corner is another twist and clue to solve the mystery.

The quirky music keeps reminding you to just have fun with The Third Man and go along for a very fun ride. The constant jokes and lighthearted jabs keep you entertained while you figure your way through this complex narrative of crime and punishment. One of the most lauded movies in cinematic history, particularly among the British crowd, The Third Man is steeped in dark atmosphere and post-war paranoia, depicting an image of Vienna as an imposing city that cares nothing for the everyman and couldn't care less if you suffer. But despite these plus points I still didn't enjoy the film, at least not as much as I should have. The performances, with the exception of Orson Welles, never feel very vibrant or even engaging. Joseph Cotton's character is more of a snarky annoyance than anything else, and Alida Valli looks half-bored most of the time. All is absurd.  The war is over, Vienna is in ruins, and the black market reigns.  The Allies have divided the city into zones, and the long reach of the Soviets is beginning to assert itself.  When a pulp fiction writer (Joseph Cotten) arrives looking for his friend but finds he's died under what seem like suspicious circumstances, he doesn't know who to trust.  His friend's associates are shady, and the authorities uncaring.  Morality itself also seems to be in ruins.

Strong direction from Carol Reed, excellent cinematography Robert Krasker, and a musical score from Anton Karas based entirely on the zither make for a unique, and very good film.  Cotten, Alida Valli (the girlfriend), and Trevor Howard (the investigating major) all turn in solid performances, but it's Orson Welles who is absolutely brilliant, though his role is smaller.  His acting is fantastic in the scene at the top of the Ferris wheel, where, among other things, he comments so blithely on doing harm to his fellow man by saying "Victims?  Don't be melodramatic.  Look down there. Tell me, would you really feel any pity if one of those dots stopped moving forever?  If I offered you twenty thousand pounds for every dot that stopped, would you really, old man, tell me to keep my money, or would you calculate how many dots you could afford to spare?  Free of income tax, old man. Free of income tax - the only way you can save money nowadays."

It's the rationalization of evil, made easier when done from a distance, which is truly horrifying.  Hitler had just been defeated after almost unimaginable sacrifice and human cost, a real triumph, and yet, evil is still alive and well with humanity.

The existential absurdity of it all is accentuated with frequent camera shots which are tilted at odd angles, and that zany zither music.  To be honest, I'm still not sure how I feel about the music.  At times it seemed to provide a nice counterpoint to the action, such as a chase scene through dark streets, highlighting how crazy this nightmare of a situation is, and at other times, it seems comically wacky, and out of place in a noir film.

The film is a little methodical in the first hour, but I thought the dry dialog was stylish, and loved the shadows and street scenes.  The international flavor and hearing German was nice.  Even if you suspect who Welles might be when he shows up, I believe the film effectively wrong foots us, in the sense of who is evil in this story.  It turns out that it may just be your old chum, the biggest nightmare of all.  It also wrong foots us with that ending, which Reed had to fight for, and which is outstanding.

Directed by Carol Reed, The Third Man is an enjoyable adaptation of the novella of the same name by Graham Greene. Interestingly, the novella was originally intended to serve as a screenplay of sorts as its author hoped it would be picked up by Hollywood execs and be turned into a feature film. It is for this reason that the story effortlessly translates onto the screen and play as a very well done adaptation. The film, like all good films should, draws from a number of different sources to use varying techniques to tell its story. Like the novella, the film is about a struggling writer who intends to find who killed his friend he was supposed to be staying with during his stay in Italy. The backdrop of a post WWII Italy doesn't add too much to the plot directly, aside of fleshing out the world and giving it a sense of believability. The performances by the film's cast are all top-notch, playing to conventions of the Film Noir genre, and having immense fun while doing so. Reed shows his craft skills in a film that never slows down and always keeps its audience interested.
I have much more to say about the film creatively as its visual language for me is the much more rich aspect of the film. Drawing from the Western, German Expressionism, and Italian Neo-Realism, it runs at a rampant pace from the very opening sequence, and thankfully never slows down. The pace of even the establishing sequence is frenetic, and may be confusing to some. However, it makes sense in the grand scheme of the film, as it's meant to set up the pace for the film's climatic sequence in the sewers. We expect to come back to a frantic scene like the opening, and Reed gives us just that. Our hero is decked out in all the Noir staples - fedora, trench coat, and a nice suit. He loves a good glass of liquor and isn't afraid to approach a woman he's enchanted with. By making him a "convention" The audience is immediately comfortable with our hero. Sure he's not perfect and in no way a "good moral" character, but we know what he's about just by looking at him. Reed is smart in playing to staples of the Noir genre so that he can focus his attention on the plot - the mystery, what happened to Henry Lime? Ms. Schmidt is another example of this. Almost every scene has some sort of double entendre going on, usually through the dialogue. Ms. Schmidt as a character for example, is an actress, which is almost always used to echo someone's own character arch in the plot. Actors are people who pretend, and become other people - and as the plot thickens, we see Schmidt do this herself, wanting to become one thing for Holly while holding onto the life she had with Lime; we're never really sure if she's leading Holly on until the last act. In the scene in which Holly and Schmidt go to a bar, they both drink whiskey, and one of the villains, Baron Kurtz, orders two double whiskeys. This is an implication that he is a double-crosser, one who isn't honest with Schmidt or Holly. "The third man" in question is portrayed wonderfully by Orson Welles, who conveys a tragic man who wants to be left alone and hold onto Schmidt, his love. This motif of "having your cake and eating it too" is in some way portrayed by every character. Visual motifs are used constantly, through alcohol, a small boy, and animals. Cats seem to be associated with the protagonist, but shown in a scene of calm, while a small dog belongs to Kurtz, an antagonist, implying that he is a "dog". Lime and Holly meet at a rundown carnival - a place of fun juxtaposing this dramatic, intense moment between friends as their friendship is coming undone. They hop aboard a Ferris wheel and as they reach the top the wheel, so does the height of their conversation. The final shot of the film combines all of the film styles that Reed employs. It is a long shot, composed to let the audience notice the background, a landscape; this is a western convention. It shows our hero, smoking, waiting for his woman, leaving his airplane ticket for love; very much a noir setup. And finally, instead of running to his arms for the smooch that would seal it all, she rejects him, off to fulfill her own life. She doesn't need a man right now; employing realism. This is fantastically executed film and one for any who enjoy Film Noir and its charming conventions.

The thrill of mystery thriller films lies only partially in the mystery. Once the evidence is unveiled, you better allow yourself to focus on other parts of the movie, such as the action, setting, music, or camera work. The thrill of The Third Man is that all of these elements (writing, directing, acting, and designing) are masterfully handled. American novelist Holly Martins (Joseph Cotten) flies to Vienna, a city that is closed off by international polices since the end of World War II, to meet with his friend Harry Lime (Orson Welles). When Martins is told that Lime was killed in traffic and is told by Major Calloway (Trevor Howard) that it may not have been an accident, Martins decides to investigate the case himself. Matters become even more complicated when Lime is revealed to be a black market dealer who sells mentally damaging medicines to children, along with other undisclosed files. This is classic noir, but the scenes are open to lively interactions. Every moment between Cotten and Welles is memorable.

Beyond The Third Man's well-paced storyline, the film proudly shows off its setting and music from the very beginning. The opening credits appear in front of Anton Karas playing a zither, the sole musical accompaniment for the movie. Carol Reed made a bold move, choosing an Austrian string instrument over the standard orchestra, but it was a move worth making. Where an orchestra can sometimes enlighten you that you are watching a movie, the zither evokes a feeling that there happens to be some guy playing music around the corner of the scene.

After the credits finish, Reed conducts a tour through Vienna with the audience, keeping us in touch with the current state of affairs. Reed never lets down throughout the picture, presenting Vienna in all of its wonders, from peaceful market squares to building debris, and eventually down in the sewers. Cinematographer Robert Krasker works well with Reed's vision, usually presenting every scene with this grand scope. His best shot is the very last one, which holds out for over a minute in silence, minus the zither. Despite the major conflict being resolved by this point, this shot is still suspenseful.

With original screenplay by Graham Greene (later made into a novelette) we have American Holly Martins (Joseph Cotten) arriving in post war Vienna to meet his friend of 20 years Harry Lime (Orson Welles).  It transpires that Harry had just been knocked down and killed by a car in the street.  At his funeral, Holly meets British Major Calloway (Trevor Howard) and Sergeant Paine who had been tracking Harry Lime before his death, investigating black market dealing of dangerous counterfeit medicines.  He also notices Harry Lime's girlfriend Anna Schmit (Alida Valli) who he tracks down acting in a theatre and befriends.  Soon, the porter at Martins' hotel lets on that there's doubt over whether Harry Lime had really died.  The rest of the story sees Martins build a relationship with Anna and explore what happened to Harry.

The film is remarkable for its iconic black and white photography and its zither score.  There are some great photographic scenes.  Most memorable are:

- Underground sewer shots, with all sorts of curved tunnels and angular passageways, spiral staircases, stone textured tiles and bricks, and distinctive manhole covers each with 6 triangular flaps
- Deserted fairground big wheel as a backdrop for Martins to meet Harry Lime
- Night scenes in Vienna with light reflecting off wet cobble stones
- Symmetry of staircases in Anna's apartment block
- Symmetry of the avenue from the graveyard with Anna walking 

The score provides a strong signature tune.  Played by Anton Karas with a zither, it has the flavour of a flamenco rift, playful but with a slightly sinister undertone.  On paper you would not expect a flamenco style tune to work on a post war thriller set in Vienna, but it works superbly well.

Atmospheric, wryly funny, always surprising.  The Third Man never disappoints.  Welles is a compelling presence both on and behind the screen.  Though directed by Carol Reed, one easily sees the hand of Welles throughout the production, even to the casting of one of Welles' most perennial co-stars, Joseph Cotten, as Holly Martins, the hapless pulp Western author who manages to stumble upon the truth of his friend's death. 

If you're looking for a thriller with a hero who solves as many (or more) problems with his fists as with his brains, you won't find him here.  If you're looking for flying bullets, explosions and breaking glass, go elsewhere.  But if you want a film that intrigues and amuses, a film with a strong, but battered heart, you've found it.

In this film starring Joseph Cotten, Valli, and Orson Welles, an American western writer (Cotten) travels to post-war Vienna to meet a friend. Upon arriving he learns that his buddy has been killed in an accident. Not quite satisfied, he does some of his own investigating and along the way meets his friend's beautiful lover (Valli). Together they try to cope and make sense of the loose ends. However, neither of them expected the shocking evidence which was to come. Who is the Third Man and where is he? Made in the film-noir fashion, The Third Man utilizes lighting and contrasting black and white cinematography effectively. Although simple, the score comprised solely of zither music is no less powerful. This movie will have you engrossed in the mysterious occurrences of Vienna. Furthermore, Orson Welles portrays a very intriguing character in Harry Lime.

Perhaps I was expecting too much after hearing such good things about this film for so long. I was brought up to believe that this film was a masterpiece and in many ways it is. The story is intriguing and involves characters which are too complex to be deemed either sympathetic or thoroughly bad. The way the film is shot, using shadows, empty streets, odd camera angles and moody shots creates an almost gothic claustrophobic atmosphere in a city devastated by war. But in the end, the films strengths become it's weaknesses, as the dutch angles and the repetitive melody played on the zither became a bit irritating for my taste. Still though, this is a classic, stylish and iconic film, of unique time and place.
